#Summary1=(human1) Hugh McGuire, founder of the free audio-book website LibriVox, explains in an interview about the site why they include only public domain books, how audio-book quality varies, and their Wikipedia-like approach of allowing users to contribute new material, including multiple versions of the same book.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Hugh McGuire discusses founding LibriVox, a public domain audiobook project, explaining how he launched the platform and its focus on freely accessible recordings of classic works, with volunteers contributing readings of various literary texts in multiple languages.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) LibriVox founder Hugh McGuire created the site to offer free public domain audiobooks in various languages, emphasizing a vibrant public domain, a community-driven approach for diverse voices, and a focus on public domain works to avoid copyright complexities, rather than newer works under Creative Commons.

#Summary4=(Llama-3.2-3B-Instruct) In an interview with LibriVox founder Hugh McGuire, he discusses the creation of LibriVox, a website featuring a catalog of public domain audiobooks, and the motivations behind his work, including the importance of preserving the public domain and providing access to these works for the public.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) LibriVox, founded by Hugh McGuire, is a volunteer-driven initiative that records public domain books as audiobooks, offering multiple versions of texts to celebrate diverse voices and making these resources freely available for various uses.
#Text=Interview with LibriVox founder Hugh McGuire
#Text=Sunday , May 28 , 2006
#Text=The LibriVox website features a catalog of about a hundred completed books , including books in other languages like German , Hebrew , and Japanese .
#Text=Why did you decide to take the acoustic fate of public domain works into your own hands , and how did you go about it ?
#Text=I think that a vibrant public domain is very important to a healthy world , and so I thought : here 's a way to help the cause .
#Text=I launched LibriVox , emailed some friends and some podcasters who where doing literary stuff , and invited them to record a chapter of Joseph Conrad 's Secret Agent .
#Text=Things have grown steadily since .
#Text=By the way , AKMA was the first guy I know of to do something like this , with Lawrence Lessig 's Free Culture .
#Text=That , I think , started my thinking about this , but it took a while for the idea to crystallize .
#Text=Hugh McGuire with some books that have not yet been acoustically liberated .
#Text=Do you personally record audiobooks , and did you already do so before LibriVox ?
#Text=LibriVox was my first experience recording audiobooks .
#Text=I still do the odd chapter , but i am a bit delinquent in finishing some of them these days !
#Text=Is there a particular LibriVox book which you think stands out because of the quality , the overall effort involved , its popularity , or for some other reason ?
#Text=My personal favourite is Notes from the Underground ( Dostoyevsky ) .
#Text=Other random good ones :
#Text=Austen , Jane .
#Text=Pride and Prejudice
#Text=Christie , Agatha .
#Text=The Mysterious Affair at Styles
#Text=London , Jack .
#Text=White Fang
#Text=Macaulay , Thomas Babington .
#Text=History of England ( Volume 1 , Chapter 1 )
#Text=Marx , Karl and Engels , Friedrich .
#Text=The Communist Manifesto ( solo )
#Text=Twain , Mark .
#Text=A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur 's Court ( solo )
#Text=Ed. : See the LibriVox catalog for a full index .
#Text=Browsing the catalog , I find that the quality of the spoken audio varies greatly from text to text or even from chapter to chapter .
#Text=If someone wanted to re-record a chapter because they did n't like the speaker , would you then offer two versions ?
#Text=Yes .
#Text=We take the Wikipedia approach : if you think it should be better , please help it be so .
#Text=You 'll note we offer a couple of versions of some books .

#Text=Indeed our weekly poetry project celebrates this diversity of voice : each week a new short poem is chosen and as many readers as wish to record a version , so you get 20 + versions of the same poem , a very interesting audio experience .
#Text=Besides works whose copyright has expired , there is an increasing number of modern books available under Creative Commons and similar licenses .
#Text=You mentioned Larry Lessig 's Free Culture , but it also includes some out of print titles by publishers who are open to the concept , such as O'Reilly .
#Text=Do you want to limit the scope of LibriVox strictly to old public domain works , or do you have plans to include recent works under reasonably permissive licenses as well ?
#Text=We are only doing public domain works , for a number of reasons , partly to keep simplicity in our copyright situation -- public domain means it s as simple as can be .
#Text=CC makes things more complex .
#Text=Also , there are other sites , notably podiobooks.com , which are better suited to CC works than LibriVox .
#Text=we find it makes things clear and easy to say : published works , public domain , and leave it at that .
#Text=As far as I can tell , podiobooks.com features " free as in beer " content — material which you can download , but which is n't under a free content license .
#Text=Instead of " public domain " , would n't " free content " work just as well , using something like the Free Content Definition to limit the scope ?

#Text=This needs more discussion obviously : we chose public domain because the texts we use are public domain and we did n't want to add new restrictions , especially not non-commercial , since already our recordings are being used for a number of commercialish projects ( I ca n't recall any specific project names , but some pay - education sites use LV stuff ) .
#Text=That 's good and well and fine with us .
#Text=We do n't want to have to give anyone permission to use our recordings , we want anyone to use them for whatever they want .
#Text=Also , for the thing to work you need to have many dedicated volunteers willing to do the management ( onerous ) and many willing to do the reading .
#Text=While Pride and Prejudice will attract many readers , I do n't know about O'Reilly 's latest tome on XML ... though I might be wrong .
